questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right coronary artery. The condition is likely to cause a ​decrease in blood supply through all of the following blood vessels except:
questions.solution:
Circumflex artery is not a branch of the right coronary artery. It is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The branches of the right coronary artery are:

  • Right conal artery - It is the first branch of the right coronary artery.
  • Artery of the SA node 
  • Acute right marginal artery 
  • Posterior interventricular artery (in 65% population)
  • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have

choices.text: Low plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability, and upper extremity muscle spasms.
High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 levels and tetany. (Not tetanus, caused by an infection of bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to decreased excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high phosphate levels. 

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

A hand being held similarly to Trousseau's sign (above).

Related Pearl: Summary of hormones that regulate Ca2+ levels

Parathyroid hormone
Vitamin D
Calcitonin

questions.text: Which is the largest human plasma lipoprotein?
questions.solution:
Chylomicrons are the largest among plasma lipoproteins, which are especially rich in triacylglycerol.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presenting with fatigue and weakness shows the following laboratory values: Hemoglobin 9 gm%; MCV  70 fl; MCH 22 pg/cell; and RDW 28. There is no history of blood transfusion. The peripheral smear is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above peripheral smear showing microcytic, hypochromic blood picture with pencil cells implies that the most likely diagnosis for the patient is iron-deficiency anemia. 

Hemogram:

  • MCV of 70 fl is suggestive of microcytosis (normal MCV is 82–96 fl)
  • MCH of 22 pg is suggestive of hypochromia (normal MCH is 27–33 pg/cell)
  • Red cell distribution width (RDW) of 28 is suggestive of anisocytosis (normal RDW is 11.5-14.5%).

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor______
questions.solution:
Betamethasone is indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.

Dexamethasone, another long-acting glucocorticoid is also indicated. It has benefits such as less risk of intraventricular hemorrhage and a shorter length of stay in the NICU.

Maternal administration of glucocorticoids is advised in preterm labor when the period of gestation is less than 34 weeks. Intramuscular injection of either betamethasone or dexamethasone is given.

Dosage: 

  • Betamethasone(Betnesol): Two doses of 12 mg each, given 24 hours apart.
  • Dexamethasone: Four doses of 6 mg each, given every 12 hours.

This helps in fetal lung maturation and minimizes the incidence of:

  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis

It is beneficial when the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours after the first dose.

questions.text: The following postmortem staining is seen in ____?
questions.solution:
The image above is characteristic of Cherry red postmortem lividity. It is seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.

questions.text: The only abductor of the vocal cord is ______
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of vocal cords.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: A lady wants LASIK surgery for her daughter. Which of the following is not an eligibility criteria for LASIK?

choices.text: Stable refraction for the past 1 year

questions.solution:
Age of 15 years is not a criteria for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age.

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed

  • using excimer laser
  • in individuals aged > 18 years
  • in individuals who have a stable refractive error
  • in individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment
  • in individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out

questions.text: Immunization is ____.
questions.solution:
Immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific protection.

  • Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that disease will ever occur.
  • Population strategy and high risk strategy are used as part of primary prevention.
  • Examples: Immunization, sanitation, and protection of food.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect ____
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who don’t have the disease or the true negatives.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, the supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised to all patient of dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzyme levels. Liver biopsy revealed an accumulation of dark melanin like pigment in the hepatocytes. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with dark pigment deposition (image below) in the liver. These features are suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome.

In Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) there is defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various compounds like epinephrine metabolites causing the liver to appear black.

Rotor syndrome also has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but there is no pigmentation of the liver. Serum bilirubin levels are not helpful in differentiating between Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) and Rotor's syndrome as both these conditions present with mild elevation of serum bilirubin.

These two conditions can be differentiated as follows:

Test Rotor Syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized

Gall bladder not visualised 

Impaired ability to concentrate the contrast material into bile
Total urinary coproporphyrin Elevated

Normal 

Increased excretion of coproporphyrin 1 and decreased excretion of coproporphyrin 3
Bromsulphalein (BSP) clearance test

Delayed clearance of BSP

No reflux

Rise in plasma levels of BSP after 90 minutes of injection

Reflux of BSP from hepatocytes 

Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24; pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

  • Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.
  • Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.
  • Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 
  • Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:
  • Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)
  • Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L
  • Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.
  • The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.
  • But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 8 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a history of fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found in his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient would be infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles.

questions.text: Diagnose the given ECG.
questions.solution:
Lateral wall MI (and posterior wall MI) is the diagnosis.

ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6. Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI). This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 15-year-old male undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features given in the question are suggestive of Addisonian crisis.

Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones. Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes excessive loss of sodium, decreased intravascular volume, low blood pressure and eventually circulatory collapse.

The causes are either primary or secondary. Primary causes include adrenal haemorrhage, acute infection, etc, while the secondary causes include surgery, cessation of steroid therapy, postpartum pituitary necrosis, etc.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a retrograde pyelogram.

Retrograde Pyelogram is particularly valuable when IVP/CT is contraindicated and excels at providing detailed imaging of the collecting system, especially for evaluating ureteral strictures and filling defects, making it especially useful in surgical planning. 

Other Options:

Option B: In Retrograde urethrogram, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It helps diagnose anterior urethral abnormalities. The following image shows an image of retrograde urethrogram contrast leakage at the membranous urethra.

Option C: Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) provides comprehensive visualization of the entire urinary collecting system, useful for detecting stones, tumors, and anatomical abnormalities, though it's becoming less common with the advent of CT urography and has limitations in patients with renal insufficiency or contrast allergies. 

Option D: Antegrade Pyelography, performed through a nephrostomy tube, is particularly useful when retrograde access isn't possible and helps evaluate obstruction below the kidney, often being employed in patients with existing nephrostomy tubes. The image shows an antegrade pyelogram of grade III hydronephrosis with obstruction at the ureterovesical junction.

questions.text: The most common salivary gland to develop stones is______.
questions.solution:
80% of salivary gland stones occur in the submandibular gland and are mostly radioopaque.

Sialolithiasis:

  • It is less common in the parotid gland (20%) than in the submandibular gland (80%), leading to sialadenitis.
  • Parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent and rarely visible on plain radiography.
  • They are frequently located at the confluence of the collecting ducts or located in the distal aspect of the parotid duct adjacent to the parotid papilla.
  • Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify the stone.
  • A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either endoscopic retrieval, or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach may be required.
  • In the case of sialadenitis, treatment is either marsupialization or total excision of the gland.

questions.text: Identify the following incision used for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
• Lanz incision is a Transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the  umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line
  • Rockey–Davis incision : Transverse right lower quadrant incision.
  • Gridiron incision : Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.
  • Rutherford–Morrison incision : oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: Chadwick sign is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign is the dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at around 8th week of pregnancy. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

During pregnancy, there is increased vascularity and hyperemia in the skin and muscles of the perineum and vulva. This increased vascularity prominently affects the vagina and cervix and results in the bluish tint of the vagina and ectocervix which is characteristic of the Chadwick sign.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended away backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
The structure injured in an episiotomy done posteriorly beyond the perineal body is the external anal sphincter. 

The lacerations of the perineum have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external anal sphincter
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Pap smear is ________
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test. In case of positive test further investigations should be done.

Pap Smear Schedule

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear

Endocervical brush:

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a short history of facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ with no hematuria and a urine protein:creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome with

  • heavy proteinuria
  • oedema
  • hypoalbuminemia
  • hyperlipidemia.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate day dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

questions.text: Identify the following-
questions.solution:
The image provided above is that of cock-up splint and is used in radial nerve palsy.

  • Colle's cast:
  • Knuckle bender splint:

questions.text: The egg in cup heart is seen in:
questions.solution:
Egg in a Cup appearance is seen with Constrictive pericarditis.

  • Constrictive pericarditis results with calcification of the pericardium. There is a straightening of the right heart border and roughening of the cardiac outline as a result of pleuropericardial thickening. Calcification has a characteristic distribution involving the anterior and lateral aspects of the heart.
  • Constrictive pericarditis is a type of pericarditis which leads to diastolic dysfunction and potential symptoms of right heart failure. Characterized by fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the pericardium, which prevents normal diastolic filling of the heart.
  • MRI is the investigation done to assess the thickness of pericardium.

 

Note : 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of great arteries (CXR)

Egg in a cup appearance - Constrictive pericarditis (CXR), Also seen in Renal papillary necrosis (In urography)

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of normal sexual cycle.

In premature ejaculation, there is a persistent or recurrent achievementof orgasm and ejaculation before the patient actually wishes to. According to DSM-5, it is classified as follows:
  • Mild if ejaculation occurs within approximately 30 sec­onds to 1 minute of vaginal penetration
  • Moderate if ejaculation occurs within approximately 15 to 30 seconds of vaginal pen­etration
  • Severe if ejaculation occurs at the start of sexual activity or within approximately 15 seconds of vaginal penetra­tion.

Pharmacologic therapy when combined with behavioral treatment appears to be more effective in treating premature ejaculation. 

The squeeze technique is a behavioral method used on the penis to prevent premature ejaculation. Here, the penis is stimulated until just before orgasm after which it is gently squeezed. 

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Phase
Characteristics
Disorder
Treatment
Desire
Focuses on the patient's drives, motivation, and desires
Hypoactive sexual desire: Patients have a decrease or absence of sexual fantasies, desires, etc
 
Sexual aversion: A complete aversion to all sexual contact
Address issues like feelings of guilt, poor self-esteem, homosexual impulses, etc
 
Couples therapy may be indicated if due to marital conflict
Arousal
Consists of a sense of sexual pleasure with accompanying physiologic changes
Female sexual arousal disorder: Persistent failure to achieve or maintain sufficient sexual interest or arousal during the sexual act
 
Impotence: Persistent or recurrent inability to attain or maintain an adequate erection until completion of the sexual act
Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear
 
Check for use of medications that cause vaginal dryness, like antihistamines or anticholinergics
 
Relaxation techniques.
 
Determine if organic or psychological.
 
Consider plethysmography or postage stamp test
Orgasm
Physiologic state in which sexual tension is released and contractions are produced in various organs
Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse
 
Premature ejaculation: Ejaculation before the man wishes to do so, before penetration or just after penetration

Address issues of guilt, fear of impregnation, etc

Use vibrators, education, and fantasy

Behavioral techniques such as squeeze and stop-and-go

Address issues of anxiety about the sexual act

SSRIs to delay ejaculation
Pain
Subjective sense of pain associated with the sexual act. Most likely due to dynamic factors
Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.
 
Penetration disorder: Involuntary constriction of the outer one-third of the vagina that interferes with the sexual act.

Help with issues of anxiety and tension about the sexual act

Behavioral techniques, such as the use of dilators and relaxation

Address issues of fear of impregnation, strict upbringing, religion, etc

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding atopic eczema?

choices.text: Dennie Morgan fold can be found under lower eyelid
It has an extensor distribution in the adult phase

questions.solution:
Option (c) is not true as atopic eczema has a flexural distribution. 

  • Only in infantile type there is an extensor distribution.
  • Atopic dermatitis is an itchy, chronic or chronically relapsing inflammatory skin condition that often starts in early childhood (usually before 2 years of age)
  • The rash is characterized by erythema, itchy papules/papulovesicles (occasionally vesicles in infants) which may become excoriated and lichenified.
  • AD is frequently associated with other atopic conditions in the individual or other family member and in patients harbouring a filaggrin mutation.
  • Dennie morgan fold is found under lower eyelid.
  • Allergic shiners is the periorbital pigmentation found under the eyelids.
  • Allergic salute is the horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge.

 

Image: Signs of Allergy

questions.text: All are causes of high RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) except:
questions.solution:
Subacute thyroiditis shows low uptake of radioactive iodine as it involves destruction and inflammation of the thyroid follicles, which also accounts for the thyrotoxic symptoms due to exocytosis of the hormone.

The other three are classical examples of high RAIU.

Radioactive Iodine Scan:

  • Nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the aetiology of hyperthyroidism.
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a high (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates either inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed hormone into the circulation or an extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone, such as in patients with factitious thyrotoxicosis and in patients with struma ovari.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Increased Hormone Synthesis (Increased RAIU) Release of Preformed Hormone (Decreased RAIU)
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Drug induced—amiodarone
  • Iodine
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma
  • Thyroiditis—acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, subacute thyroiditis
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis 
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Radiation thyroiditis
